thread.title: JPMorgan Said to Pay $136 Million in Debt Collection Accord
thread.title_full: JPMorgan Said to Pay $136 Million in Debt Collection Accord - Bloomberg Business

author: Christie Smythe
title: JPMorgan Said to Pay $136 Million in Debt Collection Accord
text:
JPMorgan Chase & Co. agreed to pay $136 million and change its credit-card collection practices after regulators found it used abusive tactics to collect consumer debt, a person familiar with the matter said.
JPMorgan’s Chase Bank USA and Chase Bankcard Services Inc. allegedly pursued the wrong borrowers, seeking incorrect amounts or so-called zombie debt that was too old, said the person, who requested anonymity because the accord isn’t public.
The deal with the New York-based bank was hammered out by 47 states, the District of Columbia and the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau as they seek to clean up tactics in the $13 billion consumer-debt-collection industry.
The settlement is JPMorgan’s second in two years over its debt-collection practices. In September 2013, the bank was ordered by the U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency to refund more than $300 million to customers. The company neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing.
Andrew Gray, a spokesman for JPMorgan, and the offices of Iowa Attorney General Tom Miller and New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, who often take the lead in multistate settlements, declined to comment.
Robo-Signing JPMorgan’s units allegedly sold uncollectible accounts to third-party debt buyers and got judgments without following proper procedures, a practice known as robo-signing, the person familiar with the matter said.
From 2009 to 2013, the bank recovered about $4.5 billion from defaulted accounts through collection lawsuits and from selling defaulted accounts to debt buyers, the person said.
As part of the deal with the CFPB and the states, New York-based JPMorgan agreed to stop collections actions on approximately 528,000 consumers against whom it won judgments between January 2009 and June 30, 2014, the person said.
In 2011, the consumer protection bureau penalized American Express Co. for falsely telling consumers that paying old debt would improve their credit scores. The company paid $112.5 million in fines and restitution. The federal agency has also taken action against Bank of America Corp. and Synchrony Bank over credit-card marketing practices.
About 77 million American consumers have debt ranging from $25 to $125,000 that are subject to collection, according to the consumer protection bureau. Most don’t know of the issues until they receive calls from debt collectors or review their credit reports, the agency said in a report this year.
The JPMorgan accord was reported earlier by Reuters.
